reproductions:
Some images in this collection are described in groups; others are described individually. In some cases, all of the images in the group display online, in other cases they do not.

You can download online images yourself. Alternatively, you can purchase copies of various types.

  1. Determine whether the desired materials can be retrieved online.
    • Look in the Medium field above to determine whether the description is for one photograph or more than one.
    • If the description is for a single item and it is displaying, you can download or purchase a print. Cite the number that begins with "LC-DIG..." when purchasing copies through Library of Congress Duplication Services.
    • If the description is for more than one item and there is a "Click for more images" icon displaying, select that. Individual images will display; you can download or purchase prints. Cite the number that begins with "LC-DIG..." when purchasing copies through Library of Congress Duplication Services.
    • If the description is for more than one item and there is no "Click for more images" icon displaying, return to the "About this Item" tab and select the "Check for online items from this group" link. Then select the "Obtaining Copies" tab for any retrieved items that are of interest.
  2. If the images do not display online -- Select images for reproduction through one of these methods:
    • Visit the Prints & Photographs Reading Room and request to view the group (general information about service in the reading room is available at: https://www.loc.gov/rr/print/info/001_ref.html).
    • P&P reading room staff can provide up to 15 photocopies of items per calendar year. (Color images cannot be photocopied.) For assistance, see our Ask a Librarian page. OR
    • Hire a freelance researcher to do further selection for you (a list of researchers is available at: https://www.loc.gov/rr/print/resource/013_pic.html).

Purchasing Copies

Library of Congress Duplication Services can make copies of various types from images in Prints & Photographs Division Collections. Price lists, contact information, and order forms are available on the Duplication Services Web site.

Carol M. Highsmith sells prints of her photographs at: http://photographsamerica.com/ External .
rights:
The Library of Congress does not own rights to material in its collections. Therefore, it does not license or charge permission fees for use of such material and cannot grant or deny permission to publish or otherwise distribute the material.

Ultimately, it is the researcher's obligation to assess copyright or other use restrictions and obtain permission from third parties when necessary before publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the Library's collections.

For information about reproducing, publishing, and citing material from this collection, as well as access to the original items, see: Carol M. Highsmith - Rights and Restrictions Information

related_items.title: Gaither at Kensington. Mr. George R. Gaither, the Republican nominee for governor of Maryland, will speak in the Town Hall at Kensington Friday, October 4, 1907 commencing at 8 P.M. Addresses will also be made by Mr. Hammond Orner candidate for

description: Dr. Hari P. Close--a pastor, educator, funeral home owner, and funeral service licensee--is a first-generation funeral service professional based in Baltimore, Maryland. In this interview, Dr. Close discusses the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on small, urban boutique funeral homes, his current role as the Board Chairman for the National Funeral Directors and Morticians Association, and his observations about the pandemic’s disproportionate impact on communities of color. Note:This interview has a main camera malfunction approximately thirty minutes into the discussion. The documentarians continued the interview with a backup camera.
partof: reflections on the covid-19 pandemic from last responders: covid-19 american history project, 2023-2024

description: As early as elementary school, Carlton C. Douglass knew that he wanted to be a funeral service professional. In this interview, Douglass, a five-plus decade licensee, speaks about the exorbitant cost of dying in the twenty-first century, the long-term impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in African American communities, and how this public health emergency differed from other emergencies in the U.S. since the 1940s and 1950s. Mr. Douglass’ funeral home is in the Gwynn Oak Neighborhood of Baltimore, Maryland. Before filming, the interview started with an introduction and the recording commenced mid-conversation.

description: Lisa Sasser talks about her experiences as a historic preservation architect working for the U.S. National Park Service (NPS). The first woman to complete the NPS Preservation Trades Training Program at Williamsport, Maryland (a three year hands-on training program in carpentry, joinery, masonry, roofing and building trades used for the preservation, stabilization and restoration of historic structures), she describes her multi-faceted work for NPS as an architect, construction crew chief, tradesperson in the field, manager, and hands-on trainer. She also discusses her involvement and leadership roles with organizations such as the Preservation Trades Network and the Timber Framers Guild that encourage collaborations between architects and tradespeople. Recently retired, she discusses how she continues to do consulting work through her company, Quid Tum-Historic Structures Consulting, as well as conduct field training for NPS employees.

description: Barbara Colleen Bailey discusses her work as an architect with the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) in the Design and Construction Office, where she oversaw government projects throughout the western United States. She talks about her interest in sustainability, "green" building design, and the use of Building Information Modeling (BIM) software. Now retired, she highlights some of her favorite projects, such as the Federal Center South building in Seattle that responded to its natural environment. She reflects on her childhood interest in architecture and construction; her first career as a scientist; and returning to school to study architecture. After graduating, she worked for several small architecture firms and fulfilled a lifelong goal by opening her own firm, Bluewater Architects, before joining the GSA. She discusses the challenges of being a woman architect and managing large construction projects for the government.

description: Architect Anne Hicks Harney describes her role in Long Green Specs, the successful company she founded that specializes in preparing architectural specifications for other firms by identifying, researching and pricing materials to be used in construction projects and providing data for complex architectural bid and contract documents. She discusses her education and experiences working for small firms before discovering her talents and interests in researching materials and writing specifications. She explains how her job requires knowledge of material's sustainability, performance, and environmental impacts. She talks about the challenges of raising a family while working in a demanding field; the lack of gender equity in her profession; her love of the profession; and attracting more women architects to be specification writers.
